chapters.chapterTitle: The Day of the LORD's Wrath

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Zephaniah 1 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Zephaniah 2:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the phrases 'gather together' (v1), 'burning anger' (v1), and the repeated imagery of desolation (v3-5).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'gather' in verse 1 for emphasis
Pay attention to the phrase 'burning anger of the LORD' in verse 1
Observe the imagery of desolation in verses 3-5: 'deserted', 'desolation', 'dry waste'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is judging, WHAT He is doing (judgment), WHERE the judgment falls (specific nations), and WHY (because of their shamelessness and unrighteousness).
tips: Include the judgment on Gaza and Ashkelon (v3)
Note the judgment on the Philistines (v4)
Describe the destruction of Assyria and Nineveh (v5-6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the repetition of 'gather' (v1), the desolation of Nineveh (v6), or the call to the humble (v3).
tips: The repetition of 'gather' shows the urgency of the coming judgment and the need to respond quickly
The image of Nineveh as a lair for wild beasts (v6) is a powerful contrast to its former pride
The call to the humble to seek the LORD (v3) provides hope in the midst of judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Zephaniah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage? That God's judgment on the proud nations (including Assyria and Nineveh) is coming as a consequence of Judah's sin, but the humble who seek righteousness will be protected.
tips: Zephaniah is warning Judah that their sin has led to God's judgment on the nations
The judgment on the nations serves as a sign that God is sovereign and will ultimately prevail
The call to the humble provides hope for those who turn to God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The connection between Judah's sin and the judgment on the nations? The meaning of 'burning anger'? The prophecy about Assyria and Nineveh?
tips: The judgment on the nations is a consequence of Judah's sin (as the book of Zephaniah is a judgment on Judah and the nations that are associated with Judah's sin)
'Burning anger' refers to God's wrath that is coming quickly and severely
Assyria and Nineveh were powerful empires that had oppressed Judah; God's judgment on them shows His sovereignty

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, identify a place where you are proud (like thinking you are secure) and pray to humble yourself and seek the LORD as Zephaniah calls the humble to do.
tips: Read Zephaniah 2:3 and pray for the humility to seek the LORD
When you feel secure in your circumstances, ask God to reveal your pride and help you seek Him

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His judgment on the proud nations and His mercy for the humble. Ask for humility in your life and the courage to seek Him when it's costly.
tips: Thank God for His judgment on the proud nations and His mercy for the humble
Ask for humility in your life and the courage to seek Him when it's costly
Pray for the nations (especially Assyria and Nineveh) to be desolate and for the humble to find refuge

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Zephaniah 3:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the city's rebellion and God's redemption.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' and 'righteous' in verses 3-4
Pay attention to the shift from judgment (v1-4) to redemption (v5-14)
Listen for the emotional tone: warning in the beginning, then hope and joy in the end

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being judged, WHAT God is doing, WHERE this occurs, and WHY it happens.
tips: Include the city of Jerusalem (Judah) as the rebellious city
Note that God is taking away judgments and clearing enemies
The reason is the city's rebellion and lack of trust in God

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the city's rebellion (v1-4), God's righteous nature (v3), or the redemption of Jerusalem (v5-14)?
tips: The phrase 'the LORD within her is righteous; he does no injustice' (v3) contrasts the city's injustice
The promise of a humble remnant that will seek refuge in the name of the LORD (v5) is a powerful image of God's faithfulness
The declaration 'The King of Israel, the LORD, is in your midst' (v13) brings comfort and security

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Zephaniah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Zephaniah is calling Judah to repent from their rebellion and trust in God's redemption
The main point is that God will ultimately redeem Jerusalem by removing the unjust and leaving a humble remnant who will be safe
This passage foreshadows the coming of Christ (as the King of Israel) who will bring salvation to His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The city's rebellion, the imagery of lions and wolves, or the concept of God's redemption?
tips: The phrase 'the LORD within her is righteous' (v3) refers to God's inherent righteousness that the city's rebellion cannot overcome
The comparison of officials as 'roaring lions' and judges as 'evening wolves' (v4) illustrates the city's leadership being violent and treacherous
The statement 'the unjust knows no shame' (v3) means the wicked do not experience the shame that comes from God's justice

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The passage promises a humble remnant that will seek refuge in the LORD. What practical step can you take this week to become more humble and seek God?
tips: Consider an area where you feel proud and need to lower yourself before God
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you become humble and seek God's presence
Read Psalm 139:17-18 to reflect on God's intimate knowledge and your need for humility

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about Jerusalem's redemption: Thank God for His promise of redemption and ask for a humble heart.
tips: Thank God that He is the King of Israel who will save His people
Pray for the humility of the remnant to seek refuge in Him
Ask God to remove your rebellion and help you trust in His redemption
